Situation1: They review a construction project where certain elements could pose safety risks if not corrected before work continues.
Expectation2: Participate in community service and charity work
Situation2: A severe hurricane has left hundreds of people homeless in the community, and the mayor has asked the nun to help organize a major relief effort.
Story:
I sat at my desk, blueprints spread before me, red pen in hand. The new community center’s design was beautiful, but as I traced the lines, my heart tightened. The support beams in the main hall weren’t up to code—if left uncorrected, they could fail. As an architect, I knew I had to halt construction and demand changes, no matter the cost or delay. Safety and compliance were non-negotiable.

But my phone buzzed again. The mayor’s voice, urgent and pleading, echoed in my mind: “Sister, we need you. The hurricane’s left so many without homes. Please, help us organize the relief effort.” As a nun, I was expected to serve, to be present for those in need, to comfort and lead. The sisters were already gathering supplies, and the community looked to me for guidance.

I stared at the blueprints, then at the phone, feeling pulled in two directions. My duty to protect lives through my work as an architect clashed with my calling to serve as a nun. Both roles demanded my full attention, but I could not be in two places at once. My heart ached as I wrestled with what to do next.
